prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Large CO 1-0, extent of the wind

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our cycle 0 data show that the brightest streamers on the approaching side have peak brightnesses of 100-150 mJy/beam (in a 3.2" beam) in CO 1-0, and have velocity widths that can be up to a few times 20 km/s. Our nominal sensitivity was ~2 mJy/beam in 20 km/s, but the dynamic range of the data was severely compromised by the poor uv sampling of cycle 0 and the lack of ACA+TP measurements. Here we aim for 1 mJy/beam in 20 km/s throughout the mosaic area, with the inclusion of ACA+TP which are necessary to sample the spatial scales present in the wind (the streamers are arcminutes long in Ha). This will allow us to follow the streamers as they get progressively diluted through the entrainment. We use the compact configuration to maximize surface brightness sensitivity.
Note that the peak CO 1-0 flux density is in the central starburst region is very high (peaks at 3.5 Jy). The continuum is ~100 mJy. The dynamic range requirements are such that those regions have to be included in our mosaic to clean them properly. The sidelobes will leak into our mosaic at the level of 1 part in 1000 even 1.6 primary beam-widths away (essentially the outer edge of the orange box in Fig. 3), and to have a good model to clean it is simplest to just reobserve the bright region, which represents a minimum time cost to make sure we hit our sensitivity.
The exceedingly rich molecular dataset and the ancillary science justify using a relatively high spectral resolution mode to avoid confusion. We use the 1875 MHz mode with an averaging factor 2 to reduce the data rate in what is possible.

For optically thin emission the surface brightness (in K) in CO 2-1 will be higher than in CO 1-0, and it is unlikely to be lower than what is observed in CO 1-0 unless the gas is very low density (or very cold, which is extremely unlikely). For an idea of the range of conditions over which this is true, see Bolatto et al. 2003 Figure 6. Since measuring the line ratio is our goal, we have targeted the same sensitivity as for CO 1-0. The region covered includes the bright portions of the streamers as well as the center of the ionized gas cone, where we see some faint CO 1-0 emission in our cycle 0 observations. We use the compact configuration to maximize surface brightness sensitivity, and the ACA+TP which are necessary to obtain accurate ratios. As described in the previous goal, we need to include the bright region of the starburst in the mosaic. The tuning is designed to include the C18O (2-1) emission in the LSB.

The goal is to map at 0.2" resolution the start of the brightest streamer, to image the entrainment process at 3 pc resolution. That is where our "central" field is located. For the dynamic range reasons described in the previous goals we need to include 3 adjacent fields to properly clean the sidelobes. The dynamic range issues are unlikely to be as bad as for the compact configuration observations, since there will be less power in the small structures sampled with these data and we can include in the deconvolution information from the mosaic in the previous science goal. The sensitivity we target is the same in mJy/beam as in the compact configuration CO (2-1) mosaic, so we will be equally sensitive to very compact structure. With the observations in the previous science goal, we will be able to produce a combined image (0.2"+1.6"+ACA+TP) which will include all the spatial scales and yield a beautiful "zoomed in" image of the molecular gas entrainment "in action".

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Using ALMA observations in cycle 0 we have imaged the starburst-driven molecular outflow in the nearby starburst galaxy NGC 253 (Bolatto et al. 2013a). These observations demonstrated that the molecular outflow carries enough mass to substantially shorten the current star formation episode in this galaxy. It is unclear whether the gas can escape the galaxy, or only reach into the halo to be later recycled. To escape, the molecular gas needs to be accelerated, possibly through mixing with the faster ionized wind. This study will measure the extent of the CO emission away from the starburst, and the distribution of velocities in the molecular wind. It will also measure the acceleration, and provide further insight into the physical entrainment and mass-loading mechanisms of the outflow. Finally, the observations proposed here will allow us to refine substantially our estimate of the mass-outflow rate. Together, they will shed unprecedented insights in the fundamental properties of the nearest starburst galaxy accessible with ALMA.
